conclusion: To determine if the displacements of cars A and B are the same during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time graph for each car. The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the object.
The x-axis represents time (t). The y-axis represents velocity (v). The curves represent the velocity of Car A (curve A) and Car B (curve B) over time.
Displacement is given by the integral of velocity with respect to time: Displacement = âˆ« v(t) dt from 0 to t1.
For Car A, the displacement is the area under curve A from t = 0 to t = t1. For Car B, the displacement is the area under curve B from t = 0 to t = t1.

Curve A starts at v2 and decreases gradually to a value slightly above v1 at t = t1. Curve B starts at v1 and increases gradually to a value slightly below v2 at t = t1. Both curves intersect at some point between t = 0 and t = t1.

premise: The areas under the curves appear to be symmetric about the point of intersection.
conclusion: The area under curve A from t = 0 to the intersection point plus the area from the intersection point to t = t1 seems to balance out similarly with the area under curve B.

premise: Given the symmetry and the visual inspection of the graph.
conclusion: The total area under curve A from t = 0 to t = t1 is equal to the total area under curve B from t = 0 to t = t1.

premise: The red shaded area of car A is clearly larger than that of car B by an additional section in the upper right corner.
conclusion: The displacements of the two cars are different.
